banner.message: This is the rewrite of the Matrix Connectivity Tester UI. Please report any issues you find on

home.title: Matrix Connectivity Tester
home.welcome: Welcome to the Matrix Connectivity Tester! This tool helps you verify your Matrix server's connectivity and configuration by running a series of automated tests on your homeserver. It therefor must be reachable by the public internet.
home.getting_started: To get started enter your Matrix server's domain name (e.g. "example.com") in the input field below and click "Run Tests".
home.find_server_title: How can I find my server's domain name?
home.find_server_description: Your server's domain name is the part of your Matrix ID that comes after the colon. For example, if your Matrix ID is "@username:matrix.org", then your server's domain name is "matrix.org".
home.find_server_help: If you're unsure about your server's domain name, you can check with your Matrix client application or contact your server administrator for assistance.
home.homeserver_label: What is your Matrix homeserver's domain name?
home.homeserver_error_format: Enter a valid domain name, such as matrix.org or example.com
home.statistics_hint: Select to opt-in into optional statistics collection which will be shown on the statistics page.

footer.license_text: All content is available under the

notfound.title: Page not found
notfound.check_address: If you typed the web address, check it is correct.
notfound.check_paste: If you pasted the web address, check you copied the entire address.
notfound.report_issue: If the web address is correct or you selected a link or button,

results.title: Test Results
results.intro_results: These are the results of the connectivity test for your Matrix homeserver.
results.intro_no_action: We expect that you will not need to take any action if everything is working correctly. If there are issues, please refer to the details below to help diagnose and fix them.
results.intro_technical: Note that many sections are very technical in nature and are mostly interesting to technical power users or server administrators.
results.intro_check_problems: If any issues were found, please start by checking the "Problems" section first.
results.all_working_message: Your homeserver is properly configured and reachable.
results.all_failed_message: Your homeserver is not reachable or does not meet requirements.
results.success_message: Your homeserver is properly configured for federation.
results.failure_message: Your homeserver is not reachable or does not meet federation requirements.
results.support_info_description: If you need assistance with your homeserver, you can contact the following support contacts:
results.no_support_contacts: No support information is available for this homeserver.
results.federation_problems_description: The following issues were encountered during federation testing. Please review the technical details to diagnose and fix these problems.
results.federation_generic_error: Federation testing failed, but no specific errors were identified in the connection reports. This may indicate network connectivity issues, firewall blocking, or the server not being accessible on the federation port (8448).
results.support_problems_description: The following issues were encountered when checking the support information:
results.client_server_problems_description: The following issues were encountered when checking the Client-Server API:
results.problems_summary: Encountered issues during testing and possible resolutions.
results.client_server_api_summary: Supported API versions and experimental features.
results.client_server_api_success_message: Your client will be able to communicate with the server using the Client-Server API.
results.client_server_api_failure_message: There was a problem communicating with the server using the Client-Server API.
results.client_server_api_see_problems: Please check the Problems section above for details about the Client-Server API issues.
results.connectivity_reports_summary: Detailed information about each host tested.
results.raw_data_summary: JSON data of the test results.
results.wellknown_warning_description: Your federation is currently working (likely via SRV records), but there are issues with your .well-known/matrix/server endpoint. While not immediately breaking, this should be fixed to ensure reliable federation and compatibility with all Matrix implementations.
results.cors_preflight_warning_description: Your server does not properly handle CORS preflight (OPTIONS) requests. While the API is accessible, browser-based Matrix clients like Element Web may have connection issues. This only affects web clients, not mobile apps or desktop clients.

experimental_features_desc.org_matrix_msc2432: Updated authorization rules for alias events
experimental_features_desc.org_matrix_msc3026_busy_presence: Additional presence state for busy status
experimental_features_desc.org_matrix_msc2716: Import message history into existing rooms
experimental_features_desc.uk_half_shot_msc2666_query_mutual_rooms: Query rooms shared with another user
experimental_features_desc.org_matrix_msc3771: Read receipts specifically for message threads
experimental_features_desc.fi_mau_msc2815: Allows room moderators to view redacted content in events
experimental_features_desc.fi_mau_msc2659_stable: Provides a ping endpoint for application services to check connectivity
experimental_features_desc.org_matrix_msc3882: Allows an existing session to sign in a new session without re-authentication
experimental_features_desc.org_matrix_msc3881: Allows a user to remotely toggle push notifications for another client
experimental_features_desc.org_matrix_msc3874: Allows filtering of threads from the /messages endpoint
experimental_features_desc.org_matrix_msc3912: Allows redaction of related events in a room
experimental_features_desc.org_matrix_msc3981: Allows recursion in /relations queries to fetch related events
experimental_features_desc.org_matrix_msc3391: Provides an API to delete account data for a user
experimental_features_desc.org_matrix_msc4069: Allows users to inhibit profile information from being propagated to other clients
experimental_features_desc.org_matrix_msc4028: Allows clients to push all encrypted events except for those in muted rooms
experimental_features_desc.org_matrix_msc4108: Provides a mechanism for OIDC sign-in and E2EE setup via QR code
experimental_features_desc.org_matrix_msc4140: Allows events to be sent with a delay
experimental_features_desc.org_matrix_simplified_msc3575: The new sliding sync protocol prominently used by clients like Element X
experimental_features_desc.uk_tcpip_msc4133: Extends the User Profile API to support key-value pairs for user profiles
experimental_features_desc.org_matrix_msc4155: Allows filtering of invites based on user preferences
experimental_features_desc.org_matrix_msc2836: Introduces a threading model similar to Twitter for better conversation management
experimental_features_desc.org_matrix_msc2946: Attempts to solve how a member of a space discovers rooms in that space
experimental_features_desc.org_matrix_msc3575: A new sync protocol that allows clients to receive updates in a more efficient way
experimental_features_desc.org_matrix_msc3916_stable: Provides a way to require authenticated media requests in Matrix
experimental_features_desc.org_matrix_msc3952_intentional_mentions: Makes mentions part of the json payload of a message instead of parsing the text content
experimental_features_desc.org_matrix_msc4180: Adds a stable flag for MSC3916 to indicate that media authentication is now stable
experimental_features_desc.us_cloke_msc4175: Adds a profile field for user time zone to allow clients to display time-sensitive information correctly
experimental_features_desc.org_matrix_msc4306: Allows users to subscribe or unsubscribe from threads to control notifications

server-resolution.srv_found_description: We were able to find the following SRV records for the server. This means we did not have to rely on the
server-resolution.srv_found_description_suffix: entry to discover the server's address.
server-resolution.wellknown_description_suffix: entry and found the following results:

connectivity-reports.details_summary: See details on Keys and Certificates

errors.missing_api_config: API configuration is missing or invalid.

error_solutions.docs_coming_soon: Detailed documentation for this issue is coming soon.

cors_federation._context: This error solution explains when the connectivity tester tool itself (not the user's server) has a CORS configuration problem during federation checks.
cors_federation.title: Connectivity Tester API Error
cors_federation.description: This error indicates a problem with the connectivity tester tool itself, not your homeserver. The backend API that performs federation checks is misconfigured or unavailable.
cors_federation.technical_note: CORS errors in federation context mean the backend federation-tester API is not properly configured. Federation checks should be performed server-side, not client-side.
cors_federation.learn_more: Learn more about the connectivity tester architecture
steps: This is not an issue with your Matrix homeserver - your server configuration is fine.
Please report this issue to the administrators of this connectivity testing tool. The problem is with the testing service, not your server.

cors._context: This error solution helps users fix CORS (Cross-Origin Resource Sharing) configuration issues preventing web browsers from accessing their Matrix server. All steps together guide from initial contact through configuration to testing.
cors.title: CORS Configuration Issue
cors.description: Your server is not configured to allow requests from web browsers. This is a common security setting that needs to be adjusted for Matrix homeservers to work properly with web-based tools and clients.
cors.technical_note: CORS headers must be configured on your reverse proxy (like nginx or Apache) or directly in your Matrix homeserver configuration. The specific configuration depends on your server software.
steps: Contact your server administrator or hosting provider if you're not managing the server yourself.
If you manage the server, you need to configure CORS (Cross-Origin Resource Sharing) headers. This tells browsers that your server allows requests from other websites.
Add the 'Access-Control-Allow-Origin' header to your server configuration. For Matrix, you typically want to allow all origins by setting it to '*' for public endpoints.
Restart your web server after making changes and test again.

cors_preflight._context: This error solution provides detailed configuration steps for enabling CORS preflight (OPTIONS request handling) on web servers. Steps progress from general configuration through specific examples for nginx and Apache, ending with testing instructions. Keep technical terms, header names, code snippets, and URLs in original language/format.
cors_preflight.title: CORS Preflight Not Configured
cors_preflight.description: Your server is not properly configured to handle CORS preflight (OPTIONS) requests. This will prevent browser-based Matrix clients like Element Web from connecting to your homeserver.
cors_preflight.technical_note: CORS preflight requests are sent by browsers before making actual requests to check if the server allows cross-origin requests. Without proper preflight support, browser-based Matrix clients cannot connect. This only affects client-server API, not federation (which is server-to-server and doesn't use CORS).
steps: Configure your web server or reverse proxy to respond to OPTIONS requests on Matrix API endpoints (/_matrix/client/* and /_matrix/media/*).

Ensure OPTIONS requests return the following headers: Access-Control-Allow-Origin (set to * or specific origins), Access-Control-Allow-Methods (must include GET, POST, PUT, DELETE), and Access-Control-Allow-Headers (must include content-type, authorization).

For nginx, add: 'if ($request_method = OPTIONS) { add_header Access-Control-Allow-Origin *; add_header Access-Control-Allow-Methods "GET, POST, PUT, DELETE, OPTIONS"; add_header Access-Control-Allow-Headers "Content-Type, Authorization"; return 204; }'

For Apache with mod_headers, use: 'Header always set Access-Control-Allow-Origin "*"' and 'Header always set Access-Control-Allow-Methods "GET, POST, PUT, DELETE, OPTIONS"' in your VirtualHost configuration.

After making changes, restart your web server and test again. You can test CORS preflight manually with: curl -X OPTIONS -H "Origin: https://example.com" -H "Access-Control-Request-Method: GET" -v https://yourdomain.com/_matrix/client/versions

not_found_support._context: This error solution explains the optional support information endpoint. Steps flow from acknowledging it's non-critical, through explaining its benefits, to implementation details. Keep file paths and technical references like 'MSC1929' untranslated.
not_found_support.title: Support Information Not Available
not_found_support.description: Your server doesn't have a support information endpoint configured. While this is optional, it's recommended so users can find help when they need it.
not_found_support.technical_note: The support endpoint is part of MSC1929. It's a simple JSON file that lists contacts and support resources.
not_found_support.learn_more: Learn how to set up the support endpoint
steps: This is not a critical issue - your server can work fine without it. However, having support information helps users contact you if they have problems.
If you want to add support information, you need to create a file at /.well-known/matrix/support on your server.
This file should contain JSON with contact information like email addresses or Matrix IDs for your support team.

not_found_client._context: This error solution guides users through setting up the required client discovery endpoint. Steps progress from creating the file, ensuring accessibility, configuring content, to proper headers. Keep paths, URLs, and technical terms like 'Content-Type' untranslated.
not_found_client.title: Client Discovery Endpoint Not Found
not_found_client.description: Your server is missing the client discovery endpoint. This is required for Matrix clients to find your homeserver.
not_found_client.technical_note: This endpoint is crucial for client discovery. Without it, Matrix clients cannot automatically find your homeserver.
steps: You need to create a /.well-known/matrix/client file on your web server.
This file must be accessible at https://yourdomain.com/.well-known/matrix/client (replace 'yourdomain.com' with your actual domain).
The file should contain JSON that tells clients where your Matrix homeserver is located.
Make sure your web server is configured to serve this file with the correct Content-Type header (application/json).

not_found_federation._context: This error solution helps diagnose why federation endpoints are unreachable. Steps move from basic server verification, through configuration checks, to network connectivity. Keep paths, port numbers, and technical terms untranslated.
not_found_federation.title: Federation Endpoint Not Found
not_found_federation.description: Your server's federation endpoints cannot be found. This prevents other Matrix servers from communicating with yours.
steps: Verify that your Matrix homeserver is actually running and accessible.
Check that your /.well-known/matrix/server file exists and points to the correct server location.
Ensure your firewall and network configuration allow incoming connections on the Matrix federation port (typically 8448).

content_type._context: This error solution addresses incorrect Content-Type headers for JSON responses. Steps progress from identifying the cause, through checking and fixing configuration, to applying changes. Includes nginx-specific configuration example. Keep technical terms, header names like 'Content-Type: application/json', and configuration syntax untranslated.
content_type.title: Wrong Content-Type Header
content_type.description: Your server is sending responses with the wrong Content-Type header. Matrix requires all JSON responses to have 'application/json' as the Content-Type.
content_type.technical_note: The Content-Type header tells browsers and clients what kind of data they're receiving. Matrix requires 'application/json' for all JSON endpoints.
steps: This is usually caused by your web server or reverse proxy (like nginx or Apache) configuration.
Check your web server configuration files and ensure they're set to serve .json files and Matrix endpoints with 'Content-Type: application/json'.
If you're using nginx, you might need to add 'types { application/json json; }' to your configuration.
After making changes, restart your web server and test again.

json_parse._context: This error solution helps debug invalid or corrupted JSON responses. Steps progress through checking logs, validating files, checking for interference, and direct testing. Keep file paths and technical terms untranslated.
json_parse.title: Invalid JSON Response
json_parse.description: Your server is sending data that isn't valid JSON, or it's corrupted. This usually means there's a problem with how your server is configured.
json_parse.technical_note: Common causes include: HTML error pages being returned instead of JSON, compression issues, or invalid JSON syntax in configuration files.
steps: Check your server logs to see if there are any error messages about the endpoint that's failing.
Verify that the files (like /.well-known/matrix/client or /.well-known/matrix/support) contain valid JSON. You can test JSON validity using online JSON validators.
Make sure your reverse proxy (if you have one) isn't modifying or corrupting the responses.
If the problem persists, try accessing the endpoint directly (not through this tool) to see what's actually being returned.

server_error._context: This error solution helps diagnose and fix internal server errors. Steps move from checking logs, through basic troubleshooting (restart, resources), to seeking help if needed. Keep software names like 'Synapse, Dendrite' untranslated.
server_error.title: Server Error
server_error.description: Your server encountered an internal error while processing the request. This usually indicates a problem with your homeserver software or configuration.
steps: Check your Matrix homeserver logs for error messages. These usually contain details about what went wrong.
Try restarting your Matrix homeserver service.
Verify that your homeserver has enough system resources (memory, disk space, etc.).
If the error persists, consider checking the issue tracker for your homeserver software (Synapse, Dendrite, etc.) or asking for help in their support channels.

timeout._context: This error solution addresses timeout issues that can have various causes. Steps systematically check from server availability, through resources and network, to logs and proxy configuration.
timeout.title: Request Timeout
timeout.description: The request took too long and timed out. This could mean your server is very slow, overloaded, or there's a network connectivity issue.
steps: Check if your server is online and accessible. Try accessing it directly in a browser.
Verify that your server has adequate resources (CPU, RAM, disk I/O). Server performance issues often cause timeouts.
Check your network connectivity and firewall settings. Make sure requests aren't being blocked or delayed.
Look at your server logs to see if the request was received and if there were any errors processing it.
If your server is behind a reverse proxy or CDN, check their logs and configuration too.

network._context: This error solution helps diagnose general network connectivity problems. Steps progress from basic connectivity checks, through DNS and firewall, to understanding DNS propagation delays. Keep port numbers untranslated.
network.title: Network Error
network.description: There was a problem connecting to your server. This could be due to network issues, DNS problems, or your server being offline.
steps: Check if your server is online by trying to access it in a web browser.
Verify that your domain name's DNS records are correctly configured and pointing to your server.
Make sure your firewall allows incoming connections on the necessary ports (443 for HTTPS, 8448 for Matrix federation).
If you recently made DNS changes, they might not have propagated yet. DNS changes can take up to 48 hours to spread worldwide.

network_federation._context: This error solution addresses federation-specific network connectivity issues, emphasizing proper server name configuration and delegation. Steps progress from validating server name, through recommended .well-known setup, proxy configuration, verification, and alternative methods. Important: Emphasizes server name should be base domain, not subdomain. Keep example domains, paths, technical terms, and DNS record names untranslated.
network_federation.title: Federation Network Error
network_federation.description: The federation tester could not connect to your server. This indicates your server is not accessible for federation or the server name configuration is incorrect.
steps: Double-check your server name - it should be your base domain (e.g., 'example.com'), NOT a subdomain like 'matrix.example.com'. The server name is what users use after the ':' in their Matrix ID (@user:example.com).

Configure /.well-known/matrix/server delegation (recommended): Create a file at https://yourdomain.com/.well-known/matrix/server that points to your actual Matrix server location (which can be on a different port or subdomain).
If you're using a reverse proxy, ensure it's properly forwarding federation traffic from your domain to your homeserver.
Verify your Matrix homeserver is running and accessible. Check your homeserver logs for any startup or connectivity errors.
As a last resort, if not using .well-known delegation, configure DNS SRV records (_matrix._tcp.yourdomain.com) or ensure your homeserver is directly accessible on port 8448.

tls._context: This error solution addresses TLS/SSL certificate problems for general Matrix connectivity. Steps guide from getting proper certificates, through configuration and restart, to validation and chain verification. Mentions Let's Encrypt and explains certificate chain. Keep service names like 'Let's Encrypt' and technical terms like 'certificate chain', 'intermediate certificates' untranslated.
tls.title: TLS Certificate Error
tls.description: Your server's TLS/SSL certificate has a problem. Secure connections require valid, trusted certificates issued by a recognized certificate authority.
tls.technical_note: Matrix requires valid TLS certificates for secure communication. Self-signed certificates and certificates with unknown issuers will be rejected by most Matrix servers and clients unless they explicitly trust your certificate authority.
tls.learn_more: Learn about TLS certificates for Matrix
steps: If you're using a self-signed certificate, you need to get a certificate from a trusted certificate authority. Let's Encrypt provides free, automated certificates. Note: Self-signed certificates can work in closed federations where all servers trust the same CA.
If you recently installed a certificate, make sure your reverse proxy or web server is configured to use it correctly and has been restarted.
Verify that your certificate is valid for your domain name and hasn't expired. You can check this using online SSL checker tools.
Ensure the entire certificate chain is properly installed, including any intermediate certificates provided by your certificate authority.

tls_federation._context: This error solution specifically addresses TLS certificate validation failures preventing federation. Steps emphasize using trusted CAs, explain local testing limitations, and guide through validation, expiration checks, and service restarts. More detailed than general TLS errors due to federation's stricter requirements. Includes information about Let's Encrypt and certificate validation details. Keep service names, technical terms like 'Common Name', 'Subject Alternative Name', IP addresses, and software names untranslated.
tls_federation.title: TLS Certificate Error
tls_federation.description: Your Matrix server's TLS certificate cannot be validated. This is blocking federation with other Matrix servers. Common causes include self-signed certificates, expired certificates, or certificates from an unknown/untrusted certificate authority.
tls_federation.technical_note: The Matrix federation protocol requires valid TLS certificates from trusted certificate authorities. This error typically shows 'UnknownIssuer' or similar messages. For development/testing, consider using a staging environment with a real domain and Let's Encrypt certificate rather than local testing.
steps: Use a certificate from a publicly trusted certificate authority. Let's Encrypt is free and recommended for Matrix servers. Note: Self-signed certificates only work in closed federations where all participating servers trust your certificate authority.

If you're testing locally (127.0.0.1 or localhost), note that you cannot test federation with a local server. Federation requires a publicly accessible server with a valid domain name and certificate.
Verify your certificate is valid for your server's domain name. The certificate's Common Name or Subject Alternative Name must match your server's hostname.
Check that your certificate hasn't expired and that the full certificate chain is properly installed, including intermediate certificates.
If you recently updated your certificate and use a reverse proxy (nginx, Apache, Caddy, etc.), restart the reverse proxy service. If TLS terminates at your homeserver, restart it instead.

invalid_response._context: This error solution addresses Matrix specification compliance issues with response format. Steps progress from identifying it as a software/configuration issue, through updating software, to checking configuration. Keep software names like 'Synapse, Dendrite, Conduit' untranslated.
invalid_response.title: Invalid Response Format
invalid_response.description: Your server returned data in a format that doesn't match what Matrix expects. This means your server isn't following the Matrix specification correctly.
invalid_response.technical_note: Matrix has specific requirements for data structures. Your server's responses need to include certain fields and follow specific formats as defined in the Matrix specification.
steps: This usually indicates a problem with your homeserver software or configuration.
Make sure you're running a current version of your homeserver software (Synapse, Dendrite, Conduit, etc.).
Check that your configuration files are correct and follow the documentation for your homeserver software.

missing_field._context: This error solution helps fix missing required fields in Matrix responses. Steps move through reviewing configuration, updating software, and verifying against documentation.
missing_field.title: Missing Required Information
missing_field.description: Your server's response is missing information that Matrix requires. This indicates incomplete configuration or a bug in your homeserver software.
missing_field.technical_note: The Matrix specification requires certain fields to be present in responses. Missing fields usually indicate incomplete configuration or outdated server software.
steps: Review your server configuration files to ensure all required settings are present.
Make sure you're running an up-to-date version of your homeserver software.
Check your homeserver's documentation to verify that all required configuration options are set.

unknown._context: This error solution provides general troubleshooting steps for unidentified errors. Steps progress from retry (for transient issues), through investigation, verification, to seeking community help.
unknown.title: Unexpected Error
unknown.description: Something went wrong, but we're not sure exactly what. This could be a temporary issue or something unusual with your configuration.
steps: Try running the test again - sometimes temporary network issues or server hiccups can cause one-time errors.
Check your server logs for any error messages that might give more details.
Make sure your server is running and accessible from the public internet.
If the problem continues, consider asking for help in Matrix community channels or your homeserver's support forum.

wellknown_error._context: This error solution addresses HTTP errors (like 400 Bad Request) from the .well-known/matrix/server endpoint, which is the preferred server discovery method. Steps systematically check configuration expectations, diagnose rejection causes, validate JSON content, verify headers, and provide testing commands. Keep paths, HTTP status codes like '400 Bad Request', JSON examples, URLs, and command examples untranslated.
wellknown_error.title: Well-Known Endpoint Error
wellknown_error.description: Your .well-known/matrix/server endpoint is returning an error (such as 400 Bad Request). While your federation may currently work via SRV records or direct connection, this misconfiguration should be fixed as it may cause issues with some Matrix clients and servers.
wellknown_error.technical_note: The .well-known/matrix/server endpoint is the preferred method for server discovery according to the Matrix specification. While SRV records and direct connections on port 8448 work as fallbacks, relying solely on them is not recommended. A 400 error suggests web server misconfiguration rather than a missing file.
steps: Check your web server configuration for the /.well-known/matrix/server endpoint. It should either return valid JSON with an 'm.server' field, or return a 404 if you're not using well-known delegation.

A 400 Bad Request usually means your web server is rejecting the request due to misconfiguration. Check if there are any request filtering rules, security modules (like ModSecurity), or incorrect rewrite rules affecting the .well-known path.
Ensure the .well-known/matrix/server file (if it exists) contains valid JSON. The file should look like: {"m.server": "matrix.yourdomain.com:8448"}
Verify that your web server is configured to serve .well-known files with the correct Content-Type header (application/json).
Test the endpoint directly in your browser or with curl: curl -v https://yourdomain.com/.well-known/matrix/server

alerts.title: Server Alerts
alerts.intro: Set up alerts to be notified when your Matrix server goes down or becomes unreachable. You can register for alerts or manage your existing alerts.
alerts.register_description: Enter your email address and server name to receive notifications when your server experiences connectivity issues. You will receive a verification email to confirm your registration.
alerts.email_hint: We'll send you verification and alert emails
alerts.list_description: Enter your email address to receive a link to view and manage all alerts associated with your email.
alerts.list_email_hint: We'll send you a verification link to manage your alerts
alerts.email_verification_notice: All actions require email verification. Check your inbox for verification links.
alerts.register_success: Registration successful! Please check your email to verify your alert subscription.
alerts.list_request_success: Request successful! Please check your email for a link to view and manage your alerts.
alerts.missing_fields: Please provide both email and server name
alerts.missing_token: Verification token is missing. Please use the link from your email.
alerts.alerts_list_description: Below are all the alerts associated with your email address. You can request deletion of any alerts you no longer need. A verification email will be sent to confirm each deletion.
alerts.no_alerts: You don't have any alerts set up yet.
alerts.deletion_confirmed: Alert successfully deleted! The alert has been removed from your account.
alerts.alert_verified: Alert successfully verified! You will now receive notifications when your server experiences connectivity issues.

common.placeholder_message: This documentation page is under development and will be available soon.
common.wip_warning: This documentation is currently a work in progress and should not be fully trusted yet. Information may be incomplete, outdated, or subject to change.

index.title: Documentation
index.description: Comprehensive guides and references for Matrix server connectivity and configuration
index.getting_started_description: Learn how to set up and configure your Matrix server for federation and connectivity testing.
index.configuration_description: Configure CORS, TLS certificates, and server settings for optimal Matrix server operation.
index.api_endpoints_description: Understand the various API endpoints required for Matrix server operation and client connectivity.
index.troubleshooting_description: Diagnose and resolve common connectivity issues, network problems, and configuration errors.
index.compliance_description: Learn about Matrix specification compliance requirements and recommended feature sets.

federation_setup.title: Matrix Federation Setup
federation_setup.description: Learn how to configure your Matrix homeserver for federation with other servers
federation_setup.what_is_federation_text: Matrix federation allows different Matrix servers to communicate with each other, enabling users on different servers to participate in the same conversations and rooms. This distributed architecture is fundamental to Matrix's design.
federation_setup.warning_text: Your Matrix server must be accessible from the public internet for federation to work properly. Ensure your firewall and network configuration allow incoming connections.

table.valid_tls_desc: A trusted TLS/SSL certificate from a recognized certificate authority
table.wellknown_desc: Serve /.well-known/matrix/server on port 443 to delegate to your federation endpoint (Recommended)
table.srv_record_desc: DNS SRV record for _matrix._tcp pointing to your server (Alternative)
table.port_8448_desc: Expose federation API directly on port 8448 (Fallback option)

federation_setup.step_1_text: Set your server's domain name in your homeserver configuration. This is the domain users will see in their Matrix IDs (e.g., @user:example.com).
federation_setup.step_2_text: Use Let's Encrypt or another certificate authority to obtain a valid TLS certificate for your domain. Matrix requires valid certificates for federation.
federation_setup.step_3_text: Choose how other servers will discover your federation endpoint. The recommended approach is to use well-known delegation on port 443.
federation_setup.step_3_options: Federation discovery options (in order of preference)
federation_setup.option_443_text: Serve a .well-known/matrix/server file on port 443 that points to your federation endpoint. This is the most flexible and firewall-friendly option.
federation_setup.option_srv_text: Create a DNS SRV record (_matrix._tcp.yourdomain.com) pointing to your server. This is useful when you cannot serve well-known files.
federation_setup.option_8448_text: Expose your federation API directly on port 8448. This is the simplest but least flexible option and may have firewall issues.
federation_setup.step_4_text: Use this connectivity tester to verify that your server is properly configured and reachable by other Matrix servers.
federation_setup.important_note: The preferred federation setup uses port 443 with well-known delegation. This approach works better with firewalls, proxies, and is more flexible for complex deployments. Port 8448 should only be used as a fallback when well-known delegation or SRV records are not feasible.
federation_setup.testing_text: Once you've completed the setup steps, use this tool to test your server's federation connectivity and identify any configuration issues.

cors_configuration.title: CORS Configuration
cors_configuration.description: Configure Cross-Origin Resource Sharing for your Matrix server
cors_configuration.overview: Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) allows web applications from different origins to access your Matrix server's APIs. Proper CORS configuration is essential for browser-based Matrix clients.

cors_preflight.title: CORS Preflight Requests
cors_preflight.description: Understanding and configuring CORS preflight OPTIONS requests
cors_preflight.overview: CORS preflight requests are OPTIONS requests sent by browsers before making actual API calls. Learn how to configure your server to handle these correctly.

support_endpoint.title: Support Endpoint Configuration
support_endpoint.description: Configure the Matrix support endpoint for contact information
support_endpoint.overview: The support endpoint provides contact information for your Matrix server, allowing users and administrators to find help and report issues.

client_server_api.title: Client-Server API
client_server_api.overview: The Client-Server API is the primary interface between Matrix clients and your homeserver. Learn about versioning, endpoints, and configuration requirements.

server_configuration.title: Server Configuration
server_configuration.overview: Configure your Matrix homeserver for optimal performance, security, and compatibility with the Matrix ecosystem.

troubleshooting.title: General Troubleshooting
troubleshooting.description: Diagnose and resolve common Matrix server issues
troubleshooting.overview: Learn how to identify and fix common problems with Matrix server connectivity, federation, and client communication.

server_logs.title: Server Logs
server_logs.description: Understanding and using Matrix server logs for troubleshooting
server_logs.overview: Server logs contain valuable information for diagnosing issues. Learn how to read and interpret your Matrix server's log output.

performance.title: Performance Optimization
performance.description: Optimize your Matrix server for better performance
performance.overview: Learn about performance tuning, caching strategies, and scaling considerations for Matrix homeservers.

federation_tls.title: Federation TLS Configuration
federation_tls.description: Configure TLS certificates for Matrix federation
federation_tls.overview: Matrix federation requires valid TLS certificates. Learn about certificate requirements, renewal, and troubleshooting TLS issues.

tls_certificates.title: TLS Certificates
tls_certificates.description: Managing TLS/SSL certificates for your Matrix server
tls_certificates.overview: Proper TLS certificate configuration is essential for Matrix operation. Learn about obtaining, installing, and maintaining certificates.

federation_network.title: Federation Network Configuration
federation_network.overview: Configure your network, firewall, and DNS settings to support Matrix federation with other servers.

network_troubleshooting.title: Network Troubleshooting
network_troubleshooting.overview: Learn how to troubleshoot network problems that prevent your Matrix server from communicating with clients and other servers.

matrix_spec_compliance.title: Matrix Specification Compliance
matrix_spec_compliance.overview: Learn about the Matrix specification and what compliance means for your homeserver implementation.

wellknown_delegation.title: Well-Known Delegation
wellknown_delegation.overview: Well-known delegation allows you to separate your Matrix server's location from your domain name. Learn how to configure delegation files.

getting_help.title: Getting Help
getting_help.overview: Find community resources, documentation, and support channels for Matrix server administration and troubleshooting.

compliance_suites.title: Matrix Compliance Suites 2024
compliance_suites.description: Compliance requirements and feature categories for Matrix homeservers
compliance_suites.intro_text: This document defines the compliance suites for Matrix homeserver implementations. Similar to XMPP Compliance Suites (XEP-0479), these suites categorize features into required, recommended, and optional tiers to help administrators understand what functionality their server should support.
compliance_suites.core_features_description: These features are required for basic Matrix homeserver functionality and federation interoperability.
compliance_suites.advanced_features_description: These features enhance the user experience and are recommended for production deployments.
compliance_suites.optional_features_description: These features provide additional functionality but are not required for basic operation.
compliance_suites.implementation_notes_text: When implementing a Matrix homeserver, prioritize core features first, then add advanced and optional features based on your use case and user requirements.
compliance_suites.note_1: Core features are essential for federation and must be implemented for your server to communicate with the Matrix network.
compliance_suites.note_2: Advanced features significantly improve the user experience and are strongly recommended for production deployments.
compliance_suites.note_3: Optional features can be added based on your specific requirements and user needs.

statistics.title: Statistics
statistics.description: Usage statistics for the Matrix Connectivity Tester service
statistics.error_message: Statistics are currently unavailable. Please try again later.
statistics.overview_description: High-level statistics about connectivity tests performed using this service
statistics.total_tests_description: Total number of connectivity tests run
statistics.unique_servers_description: Number of unique Matrix servers successfully tested
statistics.success_rate_description: Percentage of tests that completed successfully
statistics.successful_tests_description: Number of tests that completed successfully
statistics.server_distribution_description: Distribution of Matrix server implementations based on successful tests
statistics.privacy_note: Only statistics from users who explicitly opted in to data collection are shown here. Server names are stored as anonymized hashes. These statistics display only successful tests; however, failed tests are included in the total test counts. Server software with only a single test is grouped as 'Other' to prevent potential identification.
